caption: The most amazing part of the museum for history fans. I would definitely dedicate more time for the Egyptian and Greek antiquities if you value history over art.

Egyptian pavilion is one of the most interesting & eye catching pavilions inside the Louvre museum. It consists of sculptures, furniture, papyrus, animal mummies etc. The most attractive exhibit is the human mummy, which gives a clear indication on how well the bodies were preserved in ancient times. If you are passionate about Egyptian history, this is the pavilion to visit.

This is the part that I like the most about the museum, i am passionate about the history, architecture and art of ancient Egypt, it is like being inside a piece of that era.Here there are lots of pieces and for all tastes, from sculptures, papyrus to furniture and even mummies of animals and people. You can visit it several times and still always see something you haven't seen before.

In big museums like the Louvre, there's usually a debate between Greek exhibits and Egyptian exhibits, and althought usually the Greek are more spectacular, I believe here, the Egyptian rooms take the crown.  Large sarcophaguses, including the one of Ramses III and many, many objects and artifacts will make your heads turn around at each step.

The Egyptian section of the Louvre has a few great historical artworks, well work looking through.
Fantastic exposition, like most in the museum.
Incredible artefacts, one of my favourite exhibits in the Louvre.
Likely the best collection outside of Egypt.
It's the Louvre I mean...does it even need a review. It has the smallest and the biggest painting in the same room. It has so much culture it's overwhelming. Even the stolen stuff are cool.

Mostly replicas, if you're looking for a Museum to visit in Europe with Egytian Artifacts rather visit the Vatican, they have a much larger collection and its less busy. Still the Louvre is an amazing museum to visit probably not for the Egyptian artifacts though.

The Egyptian Antiquities section of the Louvre Museum is, without a doubt, one of the most impressive and popular in the entire museum. Upon entering this fascinating gallery, I was surrounded by a mysterious and almost magical atmosphere, where the echoes of the ancient Egyptian civilization seem to come to life. This collection spans thousands of years of history, from the Old Kingdom to Greco-Roman times, and offers a unique insight into the life, death and religion of the ancient Egyptians.  What captivated me most were the imposing statues, such as that of Ramses II, which stands majestically, and the sarcophagi adorned with intricate hieroglyphs. I was also surprised by the variety of everyday objects on display, from amulets to tools, showing the sophistication and spirituality that characterized this civilization. One of the most memorable moments was seeing the famous "Sphinx of Tanis", which retains an air of mystery.  The calm atmosphere of the room, together with the appropriate lighting, allows you to appreciate each piece in detail, which transforms the visit into a journey through time. The Louvre's collection of Egyptian Antiquities is, without a doubt, an essential place for any lover of history and culture, offering a direct connection with one of humanity's most fascinating civilizations.

Exhibitions devoted to ancient Egypt are very impressive! You need to devote several good hours to it. Even people who are not interested in history will find something for themselves. The collection covers all eras of ancient Egyptian civilization - from the times of Naqada to Roman and Coptic Egypt. Something amazing!
Museums to walk by.
Lots of people, but a gigantic museum which takes more than a day because there is so much to see. Stunning

One of the best-known departments of the Louvre which exhibits a wide diversity of objects from ancient Egypt. Don't miss the mastaba of Akhethetep, the crypt of Osiris where the sarcophagus of Pharaoh Ramses III is located or the crouching scribe.

Very nice Egyptian collection of art. There was very little going on in the Egyptian part, so you could look at everything in peace, which was very pleasant. The art pieces were all very well preserved and the compartment was also very clean. You definitely have to see it when you're in the Louvre
